content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <rdf:RDF  xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#"  xmlns="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/"  xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"  xmlns:prism="http://prismstandard.org/namespaces/1.2/basic/">   <channel rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl">     <title>Life and Times of Jean Laffite</title>   <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl</link>            <description><p>The Laffite Study Group was formed during the latter part of 1975 to encourage and assist research concerning Jean Laffite's role in American history, folklore, and literature.\ufffd\ufffd <span style="text-decoration: underline;">The Life and Times of Jean Laffite</span>, the official publication of the LSG, will be published twice annually, in January and in July.\ufffd\ufffd <span style="text-decoration: underline;">LTJL</span> is devoted to historical articles, documents, and research notes;\ufffd\ufffd contributions of other materials, relating to Jean Laffite fiction, legends, &amp;c., are also most welcome.</p><p>The last issue in this series is volume XII, Number 1, Spring 1992.</p></description>              <dc:language>en-US</dc:language>      <prism:publicationName>Life and Times of Jean Laffite</prism:publicationName>             <items>    <rdf:Seq>             <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/401"/>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/402"/>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/403"/>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/404"/>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/405"/>          <rdf:li rdf:resource="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/406"/>           </rdf:Seq>   </items>  </channel>     <item rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/401">        <title>Jean Laffite, Buccaneer, Had Most Colorful Career</title>    <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/401</link>            <description>Jean Laffite, gentleman buccaneer, cultured, severe and respected, swept Spanish commerce from the Gulf of Mexico, not only because piracy was profitable, but rather because revenge was sweet.</description>            <dc:creator>J O Dyer, M.D.</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2012-06-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2012-06-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>12</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>    <item rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/402">        <title>LAG Member Retraces The Courses Of Laffite's Crusers</title>    <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/402</link>            <description>Windle Dyer of New Orleans enjoys sailing and has visited ports frequented by Laffite's buccaneers. he notes that Yucatan is directly south of Barataria and could be reached in five days sailing time.</description>            <dc:creator>-- --</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2012-06-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2012-06-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>12</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>    <item rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/403">        <title>Contemporary Descriptions of Jean Laffite Found In Galveston's Rosenberg Library</title>    <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/403</link>            <description>In the Galveston City Directory of 1857, Early History of Galveston, page 61, Co 1, W.D.C. Hall who had been an associate of early Texas filibusters Col. Henry Perry and General James Long was interviewed.</description>            <dc:creator>-- --</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2012-06-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2012-06-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>12</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>    <item rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/404">        <title>Laffite Study Group Member Purchases Galveston Site Of Maison Rouge</title>    <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/404</link>            <description>R. Dale and wife Diane Olson recently purchased the property located at 1417 Water (Avenue A) on Galveston Island, the site marked by the State of Texas as the location of Laffite's Maison Rouge.</description>            <dc:creator>-- --</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2012-06-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2012-06-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>12</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>    <item rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/405">        <title>Questions You May Have Pondered About Jean Laffite</title>    <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/405</link>            <description>How was Laffite able to supply Gen. Andrew Jackson with enough powder to obtain the release of his 80 pirates from the Cabildo jail and a promise of a full pardon for prior crimes?</description>            <dc:creator>-- --</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2012-06-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2012-06-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>12</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>    <item rdf:about="https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/406">        <title>How Many Ships Did Laffite Capture?</title>    <link>https://journals.tdl.org/ltjl/index.php/ltjl/article/view/406</link>            <description>In the Laffite Journal Collection located at the Sam Houston Research Center and Library, Liberty, Texas, there are other books, bibles, and journals that have not been published. In a journal nearly the same size as the Journal that was translated and published in 1958, is a list of ships captures, listed by name and nationality, the 73 ships captured by corsairs owned by Jean Laffite, 24 by Captain Dominique You and 13 ships captured by Captain Renato Beluche.</description>            <dc:creator>-- --</dc:creator>            <dc:date>2012-06-25</dc:date>     <prism:publicationDate>2012-06-25</prism:publicationDate>       <prism:volume>12</prism:volume>   <prism:number>1</prism:number>  </item>  </rdf:RDF>
